newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index ends up led by A share surge.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index ends up led by A share surge.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index ended higher on Friday, lifted by a strong rise in the A share market as fears eased over a possible market clampdown, analysts said.
The foreign currency B share index gained 3.01 points or 1.71 percent to 179.62 on turnover of HK$167.55 million, against Thursday's HK$215.08 million.
"The solid A share gains boosted sentiment in the B share market," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
The domestic currency A share index gained 23.22 points or 4.63 percent to 525.14 on turnover of 17.4 billion yuan, compared with 20.2 billion yuan on Thursday.

On Thursday, the B index fell 3.35 percent to 176.61 points, following the A share index which tumbled 5.97 percent to end at 501.92 on jitters over a possible government crackdown on China's soaring stock markets, brokers said.
The A index rebounded on Friday after the rumoured clampdown failed to materialise, analysts said.
A Hong Kong newspaper had said on Thursday that China's Ministry of Finance was considering increasing stamp tax on stock trading to 0.4 or 0.5 percent from 0.3 percent.
Analysts said they expect the B index to trade in a narrow range with an upward bias early next week.
"As long as the government does not introduce measures over the weekend (to cool the markets), an expected strong A share performance will likely drag the B index up," the Guotai analyst said.
"There were fairly hefty buying orders towards the end of the session today, indicating a positive opening on Monday," an analyst at J&A Securities said.
On the B share market, refrigerator maker Hefei Meran Co Ltd was the star, gaining HK$0.68 or 7.44 percent to HK$9.82. It was also the most actively traded counter with volume of 3.5 million shares.
On the A share market, retailer Qingdao Dongfang, which was listed on Friday, ended up 11.28 yuan or 197.89 percent at 16.98 yuan.
